div1.p: Connor comments that Section III of Carter's History of Yellow Fever develops strong arguments regarding the origin of yellow fever and is a complete and valuable contribution to medical literature.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Frederick R. Russell, September 1, 1924 [Enclosed in C0302018]
div1.opener:
Book
Section iii
Connor
COPY
125 Dunning Avenue
San Antonio, Texas
September 1st, 1924
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
Attention Doctor F.F.Russell
div1.p:
Replying to Miss Read's letter of June 9, 1924, to which was
attached a copy of the first part of Section III of Doctor Carter's
History of Yellow Fever, the letter contained a request for my criticism
and suggestions on the manuscript.

The manuscript is an admirable work and an extremely valuable
contribution in medical literature. It stands for a vast painstaking
effort to clear a debatable point in epidemiology which for years has
challenged the thoughts of many excellent men but without, until the present
work, convincing results.

Doctor Carter's study and analysis of the data bearing on the
question as to whether yellow fever was or was not of American origin is
clear, decisive and convinces me that this infection came to us from without.
I regard as the strongest points in his argument the (1) relative immunity
exhibited by the negro to this infection and (2) the almost complete
evidence that the only known vector for this disease came to America from
Africa.

One regrets that the archeologists have not been successful in
deciphering in detail the hieroglyphics of the ancient Mayas, as in the
present state of our knowledge of the records of that race we cannot help
but feel that there is stored in the stone markings left to us data which
might complete our understanding of their reasoning regarding disease.

I have no suggestions to submit. The work appears to me to be
complete. It holds my interest on re-readings.
